p.s: The article is devideddivided into four paragraphs with different functions.
The first and third ones are the argumentative parts of the text, while the second seems more informative and the last one appealing.

Some of his arguments are for example that way totoo much money was spend for translating and interpreting for those who do not speak English; more than Â£100mmillion (ll. 1-2) or that we are sending confused signals to the immigrant communities (l. 3) because we are just telling them how to say it and not how to learn saying it.

For his argument in the third paragraph he uses a very personal example by writing about how lucky he was for learning English so quickly when he arrived in Britain (l. 11) and how his parents wanted him to do so (l. 13).
Moreover he tells about his teacher not making acknowlegdements of his racial difference (ll. 15-16).
The argument of this paragraph is that schools today seem intent on celebraitingcelebrating difference but that he is not convinced it helps (ll. 16-17).

In the informative paragraph he's just giving the reader some information about the situation in Bangladesh, like that their society persists in economic stagnation (ll. 7-8) or the sad fact that young males, with no hope of employment, can only choose between extremists in the mosque or the gangs in the street (ll. 9-10).
The appealing paragraph includes again his clear opinion and some advice to encourage people on helping to get a better situation of international communication.

He uses statements like we have to celebrate our diversity (l. 18) or There is much to be gained in getting us all to speak English (l. 23) and advice like curbing the translating and interpreting services (ll. 20-21).
Rahman also includes some stylistic devices to give his article more structure.
For example he starts three sentences in the third paragraph with the words My parents (ll. 11-14), which is called anaphor and used to get the readersreaders' attention and focus on this example.

The metaphor But you don't learn to stand on your own two feet if someone is holding you up (ll. 18-19) is a sign for responsibility and says that we have to learn doing things by ourselves and without anyone's help.

Furthermore it's obviously that he uses the prepositions we (l. 3) and us (l. 23) to include the reader and make him more comfortable with this topic, so that he thinks about it as if it's its own problem.
Sometimes he uses short sentences like I was lucky (l. 11) or I'm not convinced (ll. 16-17) to make a clear statement.
Generally the article is written in the first-person narrator perspective from the author who uses daily language, probably to make the reader feel more comfortable.
He addresses young as well as older people but mostly those who are in touch with international communication.
The message that learning languages is important but with not enough help and attention is made very clear and still important today the learning of foreign languages never stops.
All in all the article has a great structure, is great to understand and makes the author's goal really present.
